EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
Item:  9.01
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM:  
Dan Moser, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Cathy Giammona, Associate Superintendent, Human Resources and Instruction, and Kirsten King Director of Instructional Services
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Hold Public Hearing at Approximately 6:05 p.m. on the Provisions of the Charter School Petition of ACE Charter High School to Consider the Level of Support for Each Petition by Teachers Employed by the District, Other Employees of the District, and Parents
BACKGROUND
	 
Pursuant to Education Code 47605 a public hearing is required within 30 days following the submission of a charter school petition to the district.  The petition were submitted to the district on September 16, 2011.  When requested by the district, ACE granted the District an extension for the required public hearing. 
	 
During the public hearing, the Governing Board of the school district shall consider the level of support for the petition by the teachers employed by the district, other employees of the district and parents.  The governing board shall either grant or deny the charters within 60 days of receipt of the petition; however, the date may be extended if both parties agree to the extension.  Such agreement has been reached and at the November 17, 2011, Board Meeting the Governing Board shall make its determination.
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
To Be Determined
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
To Be Determined
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
Hold public hearing to consider level of support for the petition submitted by ACE Charter High School.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
			 
Item:  9.02
			 
TO:
Board of Trustees
						 
						 
FROM:  
Dan Moser, Superintendent
						 
						 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, and Dale Scott from Dale Scott and Company, Inc.
						 
						 
SUBJECT:
Presentation on the General Obligation Bond Program Funding Review
			 
The district's bond consultant Mr. Dale Scott from Dale Scott and Company, Inc will provide an overview and update of the District's bond authorization.  Mr. Scott will discuss the District's remaining authorization under Measure E, based on changes in assessed valuations.  In light of the changes in assessed valuations and the current tax rate limitation of $30 per $100,000 of assessed value,  Mr. Scott will present an analysis of the District's net remaining bonding capacity.  Based on Mr. Scott's findings, it is estimated that the remaining authorization for the District would be reduced.  Mr. Scott estimates that the reduction would not be accessible to the District until fiscal year 2020.  The District does not believe the reduction will impact current Phase II Measure E projects which are currently budgeted between $80 - $90 million, however, the reduction would impact projects planned for Phase III.       
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not Applicable
			 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not Applicable
			 
RECOMMENDATION:
Not Applicable

Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM: 
Dan Moser, Superintendent
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Discussion and/or Action regarding Request for Proposals (RFP) to Engage an Executive Search Firm to Assist the Board in Hiring a New District Superintendent 
	 
Superintendent Dan Moser has announced his retirement to be effective as of the close of business on June 30, 2012.  Previously when Board discussions have taken place regarding hiring a district superintendent the Board indicated the advantages of engaging an executive search firm and the importance of having an effective strategy to outreach and identify highly qualified candidate to become the next District Superintendent.  As such, Administration is bringing forward, for the Board’s consideration, a Request For Proposals (RFP) to solicit for an executive search firm.   Enclosed is the RFP developed.
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Undetermined at this time
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
General Fund
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the attached RFP for an Executive Search Firm to assist the Board in the recruitment and selection of a new District Superintendent.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  9.07 
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM: 
Patricia Martinez-Roach, Board Member
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Update on the Status of McKinney-Vento
	 
The McKinney-Vento Homeless Assistance Act (Title X, Part C of NCLB) ensures that children and youth experiencing homelessness have full and equal access to an appropriate public education.
	 
Enrollment Process:
Schools must immediately enroll children who are in homeless situations (even when records, normally required, are not available)
Students may stay in their school of origin (if in their best interest)
Unaccompanied youth must be provided educational access (through homeless education liaison)
Provide transportation to school of origin (when appropriate)
Provide written explanations of placement decisions 
	 
McKinney-Vento students have equal access to all comparable educational programs and services as offered to others students throughout the district such as, but not limited to ELD, vocational education (CCOC), gifted & talented programs , before-and after-school programs, school nutrition programs and transportation.
	 
“Homeless Children and Youth” is defined as:
Children/youth who lack a fixed, regular and adequate nighttime residence
*Sharing the housing of other persons due to loss of housing, economic hardship or similar reason
Living in motels, hotels, trailer parks, car, public spaces, abandoned buildings, camping grounds, (just to mention a few)
Living in emergency or transitional shelters
Awaiting foster care placement
	 
*Families sharing housing, living in doubled-up settings, must meet the McKinney-Vento definition requirement that the living situation is due to a loss of housing, economic hardship or a similar reason.
Families who live together due to cultural preference, to save money, or to pool resources in order to provide a larger/nicer home than would be possible (if living individually) should not be considered homeless.

Transportation:
Out of 123 identified McKinney-Vento students in 2010-2011, 41 students took advantage of transportation offered to them.  The remaining students opted to have parents them to and from school or were within walking distance of their home school.
	 
At present of 81 students identified, 42 students are taking advantage of transportation.
	 
RESOURCES CURRENTLY BEING PROVIDED:
Emergency Assistance (school uniforms, PE clothes/shoes, backpacks, school supplies)
Waiving of fees for PSAT/SAT tests
GED voucher payment 
VTA bus passes
Free & Reduced Meals
Referrals to Standup for Kids Pantry (students 17-18 unaccompanied)
*In 2010-2011 students were provided backpacks with school supplies, hygiene products & dental kits (120 backpacks were provided by KtoCollege through Santa Clara County Office of Education)
Provide parents with information regarding Shelters, Emergency Food/Groceries
	 
*kits were distributed to schools through the MSTs
	 
SCHOOL NOTICES
In 2010-2011 every school in the district was provided approximately 20-25 flyers provided by SCCOE as a mandate to publicize McKinney-Vento amongst the schools. 
	 
TRAININGS
In 2009-2010 SCCOE provided a staff development day aimed at making school staff aware of McKinney-Vento.  Registrars are provided information, at least once each year, on McKinney-Vento through their regular monthly meetings.  APAs are also brought up-to-date on the latest information shared through regular quarterly meetings with SCCOE.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  10.02
				 
					 
TO:
Board of Trustees
					 
					 
FROM:  
Dan Moser, Superintendent
					 
					 
PREPARED BY:
Cathy Giammona, Associate Superintendent, Human Resources and Instruction, and Kirsten King, Director of Instructional Services
SUBJECT:
Receive First Reading on Amended Board Policy #5120.1 Assignment of Credit
	 
Education Code 51225 and AB 167 provide alternative graduation requirements for students in foster care. Students in foster care are forced to move to different schools and districts because of foster care placement issues.  In some cases, students move multiple times during a given school year. Because these students change schools midway through a semester, they often times are not able to complete a full semester of course work causing these students to fall behind on graduation requirements.
	 
The California Foster Youth Education Task Force met with other state agencies during a Foster Youth Education Summit held in Sacramento and designed a set of recommended practices for Foster Youth and Youth in Transition from juvenile court operated schools and facilities. One of the recommendations is to institute partial credits for students who fall into these categories. Education Code 48645.5 states that districts must accept partial credits earned by these students and the amendment to the East Side Union High School District Board Policy 5120.1 allows East Side schools to issue partial credits to these students when they exit one of our schools.
	 
Student Services and Instructional Services have been meeting with representatives from the Santa Clara County Office of Education, the Santa Clara Juvenile Courts, and other districts to discuss best practices involving students in foster care and students transitioning from the juvenile court system. The group as a whole is urgently recommending the implementation of partial credits for these youth.
	 
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not Applicable
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not Applicable
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees receive and review the first reading of amended Board Policy #5120.1 Assignment of Credit.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  10.03
				 
					 
TO:
Board of Trustees
					 
					 
FROM:  
Dan Moser, Superintendent
					 
					 
PREPARED BY:
Cathy Giammona, Associate Superintendent, Human Resources and Instruction, and Kirsten King, Director of Instructional Services
SUBJECT:
Approve Calero High School as an Alternative School
	 
Formal Establishment of Calero High School
	 
Background: In order to officially open a new school and obtain authorization and recognition from the California Department of Education, the Board must take action to establish the new school. Once this occurs, the California Department of Education will approve the request and assign a California Directory of Schools (CDS) number.  This number is required because it identifies the site for funding, reporting, and overall operating purposes.
	 
Proposed High School: The East Side Union High School District intends to open a new Alternative High School called Calero High School in September 2012 barring any construction delays; otherwise, it will open in January 2013. The school will serve approximately 320 students in an Alternative High School setting, grades 9-12. Enrollment at Calero will be voluntary for both students and staff and will be considered a school of choice.
	 
Facilities:  Calero High School will be located at 420 Calero Ave. San Jose, CA 95123. The East Side Union High School District purchased this property in 2008/09 with the intent of opening another high school. The property originally served as an elementary school in the Oak Grove School District. After many years of use by the Oak Grove School District and subsequent occupation by a Santa Clara County Office of Education Community Day School, it was necessary to design an extensive remodel prior to opening a new high school to serve students within the East Side Union High School District. Remodel efforts are underway.
	 
Program Overview: Calero will be an Alternative Education High School which will offer options for students who find the traditional high school environment a challenge. Students are offered small class sizes, individualized attention, and a flexible schedule allowing them to attend CCOC, Community College, and participate in Work Experience. The goal of this program is to graduate students and prepare them for post-secondary educational programs and/or careers. Students will be offered a full range of classes, including self-paced performance-based courses, which will allow students to recover credit and course requirements, accelerate to grade level, and take advanced course work.
	 
Calero High School will also offer a Virtual Academy which will utilize an online curriculum allowing students to complete coursework at their own pace so that they can recover credit and graduate at an accelerated rate. Another advantage of this program will be to provide an alternative environment and daily schedule that accommodates the needs of students who cannot attend a comprehensive high school. Students in this program will attend classes for 4 hours per day to receive instruction and individualized help and will continue their study at home in the virtual environment. Two 4 hour sessions accommodating a total of 60 students will rotate through the program each day.
	 
All state-mandated testing such as STAR, CAHSEE, and CELDT will be administered according to state mandates to the appropriate students at Calero High School. The school will seek WASC accreditation during the first year of operation. The school will offer courses approved by the East Side Union High School District which has a full roster of UC/CSU A-G approved courses.
	 
Staffing:  The district will begin hiring teachers, administrators, and support staff in late spring or early summer of 2012.
	 
Budget: Calero High School will have its own operating budget using the same formulas for funding that are used for the other high schools within the district. The budget will be Board-approved prior to the opening of the school in spring of 2012.
	 
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not Applicable
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
As per salary schedule
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board approve the establishment of a new alternative education high school called Calero High School.

The board asked for a presentation on the issues surrounding creating a common grading policy. SUBJECT:
Receive First Reading of New Board Policy #5120.3
	 
	 
East Side Union High School District grading policies are found within many different board policies.  The main policies that contain references to grading are:
	 
6155.1 Grades/Evaluation of Student Achievement
5120.1 Assignment of Credit
5113 Absences and Excuses
6154 Homework/Makeup work
5121 Grades Evaluation of Student Achievement
5126 Awards of Achievement
	 
All of the grading policies referenced in board policy were brought to the Instructional Policies Committee (IPC) in the Fall of 2010 as a discussion item.  The IPC Committee found that it would be beneficial to add one comprehensive board policy that stated all references to grading while keeping the current references to grading while keeping the current references in grading in existing board policy.
	 
The new proposed Board Policy #5120.3 is a compilation of the board polices that reference grading.

Not Applicable

As per salary schedule

SUBJECT:
Receive the Second Valenzuela/CASHEE and Williams Settlement Uniform Complaint Quarterly Report for Period Covering July 1st  through September 30, 2011 as required by EC 35186 (Williams Settlement Legislation SB550 and AB2727)
	 
	 
Background
As a result of the Williams Case (EC 35186), referred to as a landmark Superior Court case requires that every California public school provide each student with, at the very least, sufficient textbooks and instructional materials; clean, safe and functional buildings and facilities; and permanent, appropriately trained and assigned teachers.  Additionally, under the settlement of the Valenzuela/CASHEE Settlement (EC 37254) students in grades 10 to 12 inclusive shall be notified of services available to students up to two consecutive years after the completion of grade 12 who have not yet passed the CAHSEE.
	 
School districts shall support summarized data on the nature and resolution of all Williams Complaints and Valenzuela/CAHSEE Complaints on a quarterly basis to the governing board and the county superintendent of schools.  The report shall include the number of complaints by the general subject area with the number of resolved and unresolved complaints.
	 
The attached report indicates the number of complaints filed from July 1, 2011 through September 30, 2011.
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
None
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Senate Bill 6 (Williams)
State Instructional Materials Allocation
District Instructional Materials Budget
Other Categorical funds as Appropriate
	 
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees accept the second Quarterly Valenzuela/CASHEE and Williams Settlement Uniform Complaint report for the period covering July 1, 2011 through September 30, 2011, as required by EC 35186 (Williams Settlement Legislation SB550 and AB2727).

Item:  11.06 
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM: 
Dan Moser, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent, Business Services, and Gail Beal, Keenan & Associates
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Adopt Resolution #2011/2012-08 Supplemental Early Retirement Plan (SERP) for Certificated Bargaining Unit Members
	 
* * *
DISCLOSURE OF POTENTIAL CONFLICT OF INTEREST
The subject matter of this Agenda item (Supplemental Early Retirement Plan (SERP)) raises a potential conflict of interest insofar as the eligibility criteria developed by Keenan and Associates could, if adopted and approved by the Board, result in a monetary benefit to the spouse of Superintendent Dan Moser.  For that reason, and upon the guidance and advice of the District’s Legal Counsel, the Superintendent will recuse himself from the Board discussion and consideration of this matter and will recuse himself from any involvement in the creation and administration of the SERP if it is approved by the Board in its current proposed form or as it may be amended or modified.
* * *
The District is requesting the Board’s consideration of a Supplemental Early Retirement Plan (SERP) to be offered to all Certificated (non-management) employees in order to provide an incentive to employees, in the form of an IRS-qualified annuity.   The District last offered a SERP in FY 2002-03 in which 70 certificated employees elected to take advantage of the opportunity. 
	 
The District initiated a request to have a SERP analysis completed by the financial services firm of Keenan and Associates.  The results of the SERP were very encouraging and indicated that the District had a large number of retirement eligible employees who could take advantage of this program. After evaluating District information, Keenan and Associates recommended parameters for eligibility including a minimum of fifteen (15) years of service and a minimum age of fifty-five (55).  It was shown that at least 209 employees were eligible based on this criteria with the bulk being between the ages of 58 – 64.  If approved, the District would offer an annuity based on 75% of the employee’s salary which will be paid out as an annuity.  The employee can select from a variety of payout options based on the employee’s needs.   
	 
The District has gone beyond the parameters presented by Keenan and Associates to ensure that the assumptions are realistic and that the targeted savings goals are realized. The District’s normal annual attrition for retirees is approximately 22 and the District has established a goal of 85 retirees under the plan. The District realizes that this is a very aggressive target, however, a full analysis will be completed and a final recommendation will be presented to the Board once all SERP enrollment information has been reviewed. 
	 
A commission amount of 5% would be paid to the plan administrator Keenan and Associates and is based on total premiums included in the plan benefits.  The plan recognizes saving based on a salary differential of a replacement employee.  The plan, as presented, is estimated to generate net cumulative savings to the district of $2.6 million over a 5 year period.
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
$2.6 million in savings over 5 years (est.)
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
General Fund benefit
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommend that the Board of Trustees adopt Resolution #2011/2012-08 to authorize and direct Associate Superintendent, Human Resources and Associate Superintendent, Business Services to: 1) Execute the Plan and any and all other documents necessary or proper to implement the Plan;  2) Contract with Keenan Financial Services as contract administrator to provide all services described in the contract at a rate not to exceed 5% of premium costs; 3) Execute any and all documents, including any amendment to the Plan, necessary or proper to maintain favorable determination of the Plan, and  4) Enter into any other contract or agreement which he or she deems necessary or proper to administer and/or fund the Plan and to attain and maintain the income tax qualification of the Plan under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, as amended.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
			 
Item:  12.01
			 
TO:
Board of Trustees
						 
						 
FROM:  
Dan Moser, Superintendent
						 
						 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, Kathy Lanford, Assistant Director, Construction/Facilities, and Donna Bertrand, C.P.M., Contracts Administration Coordinator
						 
						 
SUBJECT:
Adopt Resolution #2011/2012-09 Approving Authorization to Enter into Contracts to Accommodate Emergency Remediation at Evergreen Valley High School for Safety Reasons
			 
			 
There was a window failure at the northeast corner of the Gymnasium at Evergreen Valley High School on August 17, 2011 which sheared off the lever to an exit door.  This was the second occurrence of a window falling out at the same building within the past two years and the district believed that an immediate investigation was necessary.  The district immediately contacted (Lotus Glass) and asked them to inspect all the windows on the subject building and they determined that the window casings were failing in some locations and presented an immediate and imminent danger and safety risk to students and staff.  At that point, the District took immediate measures to ensure the safety of students and staff and contacted (Venezia Construction) to erect gantries over the entry ways into the Gymnasium to protect pupils, staff, and parents from harm in entering/exiting the Gymnasium.  Next, the District contacted the manufacturer for the windows and framing and upon their inspection they agreed that several of the windows appeared to be failing, however, they claim that they were only responsible for providing the product. Since that time, the situation has become more complex and requires more engineering investigation as to why the windows are failing.  The District contacted its’ insurance provider and they recommended (Architectural Testing, Inc.) which is a specialty testing firm with extensive experience in architectural testing to provide testing of the windows, reason for failure, and recommended solutions.  The district has entered into a contract with Architectural Testing and a final report is expected by the end of November 2011.  All purchase orders, contracts, and work related to this matter to date were performed without advertising for, or soliciting, any bids. The district believes that all actions taken to this point constituted an emergency as defined by public contract code 20113.  The district will present findings, recommendations, and follow-up activities to the Governing Board once the results of the architectural testing are complete.  
			 
Public Contract Code section 20113 authorizes the District, in the case of an emergency and by unanimous vote of the Board of Trustees, and with the approval of the County Superintendent of Schools, to enter into contracts for the performance of labor and the furnishing of materials and supplies for any repairs, alterations, or work of improvements as necessary with regard to the public schools without advertising for or inviting bids.  Administration is requesting that the Board of Trustees approve the attached resolution declaring an emergency and effectively ratify the award of the purchase orders/contracts already issued and for future purchase orders/contracts which may be necessary should the windows failures continue at this location. 
			 
			 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Undetermined at this time
			 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Undetermined at this time
			 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees adopt Resolution 2011/2012-09 declaring an emergency situation; ratifying the purchase orders/contracts with Venezia Construction, Architectural Testing, and Lotus Glass; and to authorize Administration to enter into further purchase orders/contracts for the emergency remediation work on the school facilities for health and safety reasons.
items.item_recommendation: It is recommended that the Board of Trustees adopt Resolution 2011/2012-09 declaring an emergency situation; ratifying the purchase orders/contracts with Venezia Construction, Architectural Testing, and Lotus Glass; and to authorize Administration to enter into further purchase orders/contracts for the emergency remediation work on the school facilities for health and safety reasons.

TO:
Board of Trustees
					 
					 
FROM:  
Dan Moser, Superintendent
					 
					 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services
					 
					 
SUBJECT:
Approve the Master Business Relationship Agreement with East Side Union High School District and Metropolitan Education District for 2011/12
		 
		 
The District is party to a joint powers agreement with five other school districts that creates the Metropolitan Education District (MetroEd).  The Metropolitan Education District Joint Powers Agreement (JPA) anticipates the negotiation of separate master business agreements between MetroED and each participating school district governing their financial and operational relationships.  Attach is the Master Business Relationship Agreement between East Side Union High School District and Metropolitan Education District for the 2011/12 school year.
		 
		 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Same level as 2010/11
		 
FUNDING SOURCE:
General Fund
		 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the Master Business Relationship Agreement between East Side Union High School District and Metropolitan Education District for the 2011/12 school year.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
			 
Item:  13.01
TO:
Board of Trustees
							 
FROM:  
							 
Dan Moser, Superintendent
						 
						 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, and Donna Bertrand, C.P.M., Contracts Administration Coordinator
						 
						 
SUBJECT:
Ratification of Contracts with Cleary Consultants, Inc. for Geotechnical and Engineering Geology Consulting Services
			 
			 
Administration is requesting Board approval and ratification of a contract with Cleary Consultants, Inc. (“Cleary) and authorization of payments to Cleary in the total amount of $30,419.60 in connection with work already performed and being performed under the proposed contract.  Cleary provides geotechnical and engineering geology consulting services to the District, primarily in connection with the District’s Measure G and Measure E bond programs.  Cleary has previously been qualified by the District to provide such services and has been providing such services to the District on a variety of projects for more than 8 years.  
			 
It has come to Administration’s attention that earlier this year Cleary was requested and authorized by staff to provide geotechnical and engineering geology consulting services on the following projects in the following amounts:
James Lick High School New Child Care Center (G-030-027)           $11,957.50
James Lich High School New Two Story Bldg 500 (E-030-001)         $  2,236.25
Silver Creek High School New Multi-Purpose Bldg (E-055-001)        $     883.75
Santa Teresa High School New Multi-Purpose Bldg (E-070-001)      $15,342.10
In accordance with the request, Cleary performed and is still performing the services requested by staff.  To date, those services have been performed satisfactorily by Cleary.  The services provided by Cleary are necessary to the completion to each of the above projects.
			 
Nevertheless, the manner and method in which Cleary was retained on the above projects was not in conformance with at least two (2) of the FCMAT recommendations and the administrative and policy changes implemented by Administration and the Board in response to the 2010 FCMAT Extraordinary Audit.  Specifically:
There was a failure to implement the informal bidding process specified under the March 1, 2010, Administrative Directive and Administrative Regulation 3311 for the services for which Cleary was ultimately directed to provide, and
The contracts with Cleary for these projects were not ever presented to this Board for approval.
Administration is undertaking a continuous and focused communications, training and oversight effort to prevent future violations of Board Policy and Administrative Regulations.  This approval is sought and detailed in this manner as part of Administration’s continuing effort to ensure greater transparency and accountability in the District’s contracting practices.
			 
FISCAL IMPACT:
$30,419.60
			 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Measures E & G
			 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve and ratify the contracts with Cleary Consultants, Inc. for the services described above in the total amount of $30,419.60.
